title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: Free Swim Lessons - Intermediate
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 From 09/8 - 11/20 
 Tuesday: 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up?

title: Montclair State University Wing Chun Club Training
organization: Montclair State University Wing Chun Club
description: The practicing and learning of Wing Chun, a martial art that originated in China over two hundred years ago. In this training individuals will learn this martial art, build up relationships with other members in class, and gain a deeper appreciation for this aspect of Chinese culture. Training sessions will typically include learning of forms, learning fundamentals of movement, incorporating said fundamental motions into various drills.

title: New Jersey Small Business Summit
organization: Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
description:
Ready to level up your entrepreneurial game? 
 Join us for the  second annual New Jersey Small Business Summit  on  Wednesday, October 22, 2025  right here at Montclair State University! This isn't your typical boring business conference – it's an interactive expo where you'll actually connect with real entrepreneurs and learn skills that matter. 
 Whether you're already running a side hustle, dreaming of starting your own business, or just curious about the entrepreneurial world, this summit has something for you. You'll discover how to future-proof any business idea and master AI tools that can seriously boost your productivity and sales game. 
 What's in it for you: 
 
 Breakout sessions and panels with successful entrepreneurs who've been where you are 
 An inspiring keynote from Lloyd Pearson (Founder of Lloyd Pearson | Live With Lloyd) 
 "Expert Corner" – free 15-minute one-on-one sessions with industry pros (perfect for getting advice on your ideas!) 
 Student vendor showcases (see what your peers are building!) 
 Personalized learning tracks so you can focus on what interests you most 
 Tons of networking opportunities (translation: meet people who could change your career path) 
 
 Plus, we've got you covered with free breakfast and lunch – because nobody learns well on an empty stomach. 
 This event sold out last year, so grab your FREE ticket now if you want to walk away with real strategies and connections that could kickstart your future.

description:
Visiting the Pantry: 
 1) Please have your Event Pass, CWID and have a  PantrySoft Registration .  2) Please bring your own shopping bag and ID card! ***Visitors are allowed to come once/week***

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

description:
Not sure what’s on the ballot this November? We’ve got you covered! Stop by our  Ballot Guide Pop-Up  to get clear, nonpartisan information about the upcoming election and what you can expect to see when you vote. 
   
 Learn about local races, statewide initiatives, and key issues that directly impact your community. Whether you’re a first-time voter or just need a quick refresher, our team will be on hand to answer your questions and walk you through the ballot in a simple, stress-free way. 
   
 This is your chance to feel confident and prepared before heading to the polls. Grab a guide, ask your questions, and empower yourself to make informed choices on Election Day!

title: A Reverse Time Capsule:  What Unpacking Youth Futures Tells Us About Our Present
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
The Department of Sociology and Research on Interdisciplinary Global Studies (RIGS) present: A Reverse Time Capsule: What Unpacking Youth Futures Tells Us About Our Present 
   
 Dr. Ruszczyk will offer a framework for how youth craft futures that integrate climate change with other considerations-and discuss implications for how these futures shape our present. Speaker: Prof. Stephen Ruszczyk  Moderator: Prof. Timothy Gorman  
   
 
 
 This research explores how young people in the Global South envision their futures in the context of the social challenges posed by climate change. Based on preliminary multi method research with Ecuadorian youths, findings indicate that many foresee adverse societal impacts from a changing climate and doubt the government's capacity to respond effectively to intersecting crises. Although group dialogues generated more optimistic and collaborative visions, individualistic strategies especially migration-predominated. These results suggest an urgent need for educational and civic spaces where young people can engage in collective reflection and envision shared pathways toward more just and sustainable futures. 
   
 RSVP Here

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Korematsu v. The United States - History Club Crisis Sim and GBM
organization: The Historical Society at Montclair State
description:
Step into history with the History Club's immersive crisis simulation based on the landmark Supreme Court case Korematsu v. United States. 
 Become a Supreme Court Justice, an ACLU Lawyer, or a Department of Justice official to debate tough questions about our rights and national security, and experience firsthand the challenges faced during this pivotal moment in history. 
 This event is a unique chance to dive deep, think critically, and engage with history like never before. 
 Don't know about the case, don't worry! This is an engaging and immersive way to learn about one of the most important Supreme Court cases in American history. Free pizza will be available to all participants!

title: HT Perspectives Series - Domestic Violence & Human Trafficking: Intersections and Insights
description:
In honor of  Domestic Violence Awareness Month , join the  Global Center on Human Trafficking  for a powerful webinar examining the critical connections between domestic violence and human trafficking. 
 Our featured speaker,  Liz Kimbel , Survivor Initiatives Manager at  TurnAround Inc ., brings more than a decade of experience supporting survivors through direct services, crisis response, legislative advocacy, public training, and re-entry support for women impacted by incarceration. Liz’s trauma-informed, holistic approach centers survivor wellness and empowerment. 
 📅 Date & Time: October 27, 2-3:30 PM 
 💻 Virtual Event | Free & Open to All Zoom Registration:  https://montclair.zoom.us/meeting/register/x_fHE23xQk6u305k34EYpQ#/registration Passcode: 004669

title: Information Session- Monday, October 27, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Think Pink: Busting Breast Cancer Myths
description: Join us for our Think Pink: Busting Breast Cancer Myths, an engaging and educational meeting dedicated to spreading awareness and empowering our community with the truth about breast cancer. During this interactive session, we’ll uncover the most common myths and misconceptions surrounding breast cancer and replace them with facts based on science and expert insight. Learn about real risk factors, early detection, screening options, and steps you can take to protect your health.

title: Art Forum featuring Claire Kim
description:
The Department of Art & Design presents the Fall 2025 Art Forum series. Art Forum is a speaker series featuring artists, designers, art historians, curators, and art critics from around the world presenting their work and ideas in an open forum.   
   
 After the fall break, the next speaker in this engaging series is Claire Kim, a curator and writer based in New York. She is the Manager of Programs and Collections at Asia Art Archive in America and Director of Curatorial Affairs at The Here and There Collective. Kim will share insights into her curatorial practice. 
   
 Her experience includes museum education, programming, and curatorial work with the Asian American Arts Alliance, New Museum, and Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. She has curated exhibitions at James Cohan Gallery, the Hessel Museum of Art at Bard College, Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts, the Museum of Contemporary African Diasporan Art, and BRIC. She also served as Special Assistant to the President at BRIC and was a 2020–21 Curatorial Fellow at NXTHVN in New Haven, CT. 
   
 This speaker series is free and open to the public. 
   
 📅  Art Forum Monday, 10/27/25, 5:20–7:00 PM Calcia Hall, Room 140

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: Skills for Success: The Truth About Soft Skills
description:
Think success in college and beyond is all about technical know-how? Think again! This interactive workshop uncovers the real power of soft skills—like communication, teamwork, problem-solving, conflict resolution, and adaptability—that employers and professors alike value most. Through hands-on activities and real-world examples, you’ll learn how to recognize, strengthen, and showcase these essential skills to thrive as a student and future professional.

 Presented by the University College Academic Programming Team

title: 2026 Class Gift Tabling - Information and Philanthropy Cord Pick-Up
description:
Each year, our graduating class participates in a proud Class Gift tradition where members of the class invest in the University by supporting areas of Montclair State University that are most important to them. We invite the Class of 2026 to come together to show your support! 
 All gifts to Montclair count! Make your gift to any area of campus you feel most passionate about – such as the Emergency Book Fund, The Red Hawk Pantry, your school or college, The Fund for Montclair State or athletic program. 
 Your gift will pay it forward for future Red Hawks and kick-start your philanthropic connection to Montclair. 
 
 Commemorate your class year! Make a gift of at least  $20.26  and you’ll receive your customized philanthropy cord to wear over your commencement robe.  
 For a gift of  $40 , celebrate this milestone with your family, friends and colleagues by having your message displayed on the screen at the Commencement you will be participating in, and receive a customized philanthropy cord. 
 
 How do I get my customized philanthropy cord? 
 Customized philanthropy cords will be available for pick-up: 
 
 Tuesday, October 28 from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Thursday, November 20  from 1:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Tuesday, December 2 from 12:00 – 3:00 p.m. in the Student Center Lobby 
 Bloomfield Campus Graduation Fair: Wednesday, December 10th from 12:00 – 6:00 p.m. in Deacon’s Den, Talbott Hall  (for Bloomfield graduates only) 
 Montclair Campus Graduation Fairs: Thursday, December 11th from 10:00 a.m. – 7:00 p.m. in the Student Center Ballrooms  (for Montclair or Bloomfield graduates) 
 
 Graduates can also arrange to pick up their philanthropy cords in the Overlook Corporate Center, 150 Clove Road, Little Falls, NJ during business hours, Monday through Friday, 8:30 a.m. – 4:30 p.m. Philanthropy cords can also be mailed to those who cannot pick it up. The last day we will mail the cords is Monday, December 22, 2025 at 2:30 p.m. Please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving at stewartj@montclair.edu or 973-655-5328 to finalize options to get your cords for the Winter Commencement. 
 Every student has benefitted from donor generosity to areas of academic support, emergency funding for students and overall priorities to boost students’ success every day. Thank you for paying it forward! For more information, please contact James Stewart, Associate Director of Annual Giving, at 973-655-5328 or stewartj@montclair.edu.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: The Big 3 Competition
location: Student Recreation Center 1101 - First Floor Fitness
description:
Built Different? Show Us - The big 3 lifts (Deadlift, Squat, and Bench Press) are the foundation of true strength, and now it is your time to dominate the platform. Whether you’re lifting for the glory, the prizes, or just to beat your PR this is your chance to push your limits and have fun, all while getting to utilize our brand new strength equipment! 
   
 
 How are results scored? 
 
 Maximum 5 repetitions 
 1 attempt per lift after a warm-up set 
 Scoring calculation: Weight lifted x repetitions divided by body weight 
 Final score will be total of 3 lifts  combined

title: Red Hawk Pantry
description:
Visiting the Pantry: 
 1) Please have your Event Pass, CWID and have a  PantrySoft Registration .  2) Please bring your own shopping bag and ID card! ***Visitors are allowed to come once/week*** 
 Our Mission:   We aim to address food insecurity across Montclair State University. The Red Hawk Pantry is open to all students, staff, and faculty at no cost. title: Information Session: Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group
description:
Are you a graduate student working on a journal article for publication? Learn more about the Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group! This writing group will run over 13 weeks during the Spring semester (January 26 - April 24, 2026), with a week off in March. Weekly topics will include: publication venues, selecting a journal, writing your argument, literature review, citation management and more. We will use Wendy Laura Belcher’s  Writing  Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks  to guide the discussions and work. Register to attend this Zoom information session where we will discuss how the program will run, the expected time commitment, and answer any other questions you may have. Please contact our Graduate Assistant, Emily Cepin, at  cepine1@montclair.edu  with any questions. A limited number of seats are available. If you would like to register for the club without attending an info session, you may do so by completing this  registration form . Sponsored by the Center for Writing Excellence and the University Libraries. 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/14826371

2:00 PM  Cali Midweek Series: Stefan Jackiw  Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall, Cali School of Music 
 Stefan Jackiw  performs solo violin works and the dynamic opening movement of Mendelssohn’s String Octet with Cali Graduate String Students. Hailed for playing that “combines poetry and purity with impeccable technique” (Boston Globe), Jackiw has appeared with leading U.S. symphonies, tours internationally, and is a founding member of the Junction Trio. Artistic Director of the Hawaii Chamber Music Festival, his performances are praised as intelligent, sensitive, and deeply moving. Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall, Cali School of Music

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Delta Chaos
description:

 Together, let’s raise money, spread awareness, and honor the mission of “Don’t Give Up… Don’t Ever Give Up!”

title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: Bucket's For BuL.L.S
description:
The Brothers of Tau Phi Beta would like to invite you out to our newly founded annual events called Bucket's for BuL.L.S, This is our exciting charity shot competition that brings together participants of any skill level to support the fight against leukemia and lymphoma. This event combines the love of sports with a noble cause, raising funds to advance research, provide patient support, and improve the lives of those affected by these blood cancers. All proceeds will go to our Philanthropy The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.  
 These contests will consist of: 
 3 pt Contest - Each contestant will have three tries to make at least one three pointer.  
 Free Throw Contest - Each contestant will be given five shots and must make at least three of them to win. 
 Timed Around The World - Each contestant will be given a time limit to complete every shot around the world. 
 We will supply our own basketball net and tape for the lines. Each Contestant will receive a monster or monster merchandise of their choosing as a prize.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: FRN Tabling Meet & Connect
description:
👻 Join us for a fun and festive opportunity to learn more about our organization at our special Halloween-themed table! Stop by to meet our team, learn about our mission and programs, and find out how you can get involved—all while enjoying some sweet seasonal activities. 
 Test your knowledge with  Trick-or-Treat Trivia -  answer a quick question about food waste or sustainability, and if you get it right, you’ll score a treat from our giant Halloween candy bowl! 
 Try your luck with our  “Guess How Many Seeds” Jar -  guess how many roasted pumpkin seeds are inside for a chance to win a fun eco-friendly prize like a tote bag, sticker pack, or reusable utensil. 
 Plus, take home some creative  DIY Spooky Stickers  featuring Halloween designs and food recovery slogans like  “No Tricks, Just Treats—Don’t Waste Food”  and  “Scary Amount of Food Waste.” 
 🎃 Candy bags will be available while supplies last, so come early! 
 💬 Chat with our team, ask questions, and get involved in our upcoming events. We look forward to sharing some Halloween cheer, and some knowledge, with you!

title: “Sweatober" Challenge Month
description:
Are you ready to commit to your goals, try something new, and earn rewards while you sweat? All October long, we’re turning up the energy with Sweatober—a month-long group fitness challenge designed to keep you moving, motivated, and having fun.   Plus, this is a judgment-free zone: no matter your fitness level, our instructors and community are here to cheer you on. It’s not about being perfect, it’s about showing up for yourself! 
 Here’s how it works:   
 Attend group fitness classes throughout the month and earn class points toward a t-shirt.   Stay consistent and have a blast working out with us.  Attend 10 classes of your choosing  (like Zumba, Kickboxing, Yoga, HIIT, Pilates, Cycling, BJJ, and more!) over the course of the month and you’ll be snagging a FREE exclusive t-shirt as prize!  We'll contact you when you hit the goal so there's nothing you need to do; simply show up with your ID. 
   
 Let October be the month you commit to YOU. One class at a time. 
 When:  October 1-31 (month-long) - Reminder, there will be no classes Saturday, 10/18- Saturday, 10/25 for Fall Break- 
 Where:  Student Recreation Center, MP1 and MP2 (Locations depend on the fall group x schedule) 
 Who:  Montclair Students Drop-in is welcomed!

title: Biking Trip - Paulinskill Rail Trail
description:
Come join us on a bike through Paulinskill rail trail  that is flat and an easy trail for anyone. This trail used to be a railroad and was made into a bike path. While biking you will be in the nice fall weather and enjoying the outdoors. (Biking experience required) 
   
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Please register in the Student Rec Center main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students  $10 
 
 Where and When? 
 
 Saturday, November 1, 2025  
 10a.m. - 5 p.m. 
 Begins Student Recreation Center 
 
 What to bring: Water, Lunch, Long Pants, Sneakers, and Sunscreen. 
  Potential Hazards: unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites, injury by running including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures.

title: Cultural Soiree
location: Student Center 250ABC - Ballrooms A, B, and C
description: Join us as we celebrate the rich history, traditions, and vibrancy of Haiti! This event will highlight Haitian culture through music, dance, art, and food, giving students an opportunity to experience the heart of the island. From Kompa rhythms and Creole expressions to traditional dishes and cultural displays, the night will be filled with learning, community, and celebration. Whether you have Haitian roots or simply want to explore and appreciate a new culture, this event is open to all. Come ready to enjoy, connect, and celebrate Haiti!

title: Information Session: Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group
description:
Are you a graduate student working on a journal article for publication? Learn more about the Grad Student Journal Article Writing Group! This writing group will run over 13 weeks during the Spring semester (January 26 - April 24, 2026), with a week off in March. Weekly topics will include: publication venues, selecting a journal, writing your argument, literature review, citation management and more. We will use Wendy Laura Belcher’s  Writing  Your Journal Article in Twelve Weeks  to guide the discussions and work. Register to attend this Zoom information session where we will discuss how the program will run, the expected time commitment, and answer any other questions you may have. Please contact our Graduate Assistant, Emily Cepin, at  cepine1@montclair.edu  with any questions. A limited number of seats are available. If you would like to register for the club without attending an info session, you may do so by completing this  registration form . Sponsored by the Center for Writing Excellence and the University Libraries. 
 Register Here: https://montclair.libcal.com/event/14826381

title: Information Session-  Monday, November 3, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

description:
Here's what you need to become a certified teacher      Our   Master of Arts in Teaching with Initial Certification Programs   offer pathways to certification so that you can lead classes and drive positive outcomes for students.  
 Our nationally and internationally recognized Teacher Education Program has many unique features, which include curricular emphasis, the  Center of Pedagogy , as well as partnerships with local schools and communities.

We focus on leadership development, community engagement, mental health, academic support, and athletic excellence.

title: Día de los Muertos - De la memoria a la tradición
organization: Center for Latino Heritage & Spanish Language Excellence
description:
Join us for a heartfelt celebration of Día de los Muertos, honoring our loved ones through art, memory, and culture organized by CLaSE - Center for Latino Heritage and Spanish language Excellence - and Pueblos Originarios. Come and share with us the worldview and wisdom of Indigenous peoples, rooted in memory and ancestral tradition.  
 Program Highlights: 
 Installation of a Symbolic Altar :  A community altar created by all participants, adorned with marigolds, candles, and personal dedications. 
 “Calaveritas” - Presentation :  Poetic tributes from participants of the Literary Creation Workshop led by Marco Nieto, blending art and tradition. 
 Reflections from the Concejo de Pueblos Originarios :  Short talks about Indigenous commemorations, spiritual perspectives, and the meaning of the altar as a bridge between the living and the departed. 
 Oral Expressions for the Departed :  Marco Nieto: “From Prayer to Poetry – The Mexican Calaveritas.” 
 Thematic Music :  By Próspero Martínez.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

location: Student Center 250ABC - Ballrooms A, B, and C
description:
Join us in honoring and celebrating the rich tradition of  Día de los Muertos , a vibrant Mexican holiday that commemorates the lives of loved ones who have passed. Our event will feature a beautifully decorated altar ( ofrenda ), live music, traditional dances, face painting, arts and crafts, and delicious food that captures the spirit of the season. 
 Together, we’ll create a space of remembrance, community, and joy—celebrating life through culture, tradition, and unity. All are welcome to participate, whether to learn, to remember, or to simply enjoy this colorful and meaningful celebration.

title: AI Distinguished Speaker Series: The Truth of the Matter in the Age of Generative AI
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
location: Presentation Hall, College of Communication and Media
description:
The College of Humanities and Social Sciences is launching a new AI  Distinguished Speaker Series —a yearlong exploration of how artificial intelligence is reshaping human systems, knowledge, and society. Designed to be inclusive and engaging, the series will bring thought leaders to campus who not only explain emerging technologies but also invite students and the wider community into critical conversations about their impact. By blending expert insight with student-centered formats, the series aims to spark new ways of learning, questioning, and participating in AI’s future. 
 The Truth of the Matter in the Age of Generative AI,  with Tina Eliassi-Rad, PhD 
 Abstract We live in the age of algorithmically infused societies where human and algorithmic behavior are intertwined. Consider generative AI tools (such as ChatGPT and Gemini). Their use across a broad spectrum of our society is undeniable. How can we shape their use to improve our society? As it stands, such tools often increase epistemic instability in our society. Generative AI tools, for example, are not experts in any field and are prone to falsehoods (a.k.a. hallucinations) and adversarial attacks, yet they are treated like experts. The relationship between a person and a generative AI tool is also exaggerated by the sense of familiarity one feels when using such tools. The lack of effective oversight and accountability for this technology exacerbates these issues. How can we govern a technology that is mutating so rapidly? A digitally savvy public is an essential part of the solution. 
 Speaker Bio Tina Eliassi-Rad is a Professor of Computer Science and  The Inaugural Joseph E. Aoun Chair at Northeastern University . She is also a core faculty member at  Northeastern’s Network Science Institute . In addition, she is an external faculty member at the  Santa Fe Institute  and the  Vermont Complex Systems Institute . Prior to joining Northeastern, Tina was an Associate Professor of Computer Science at Rutgers University; and before that she was a member of technical staff and principal investigator at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. Tina earned her Ph.D. in Computer Sciences (with a minor in Mathematical Statistics) at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Her research is at the intersection of data mining, machine learning, and network science. She has over 150 peer-reviewed publications (including a few best paper and best paper runner-up awards); and has given over 300 invited talks and 14 tutorials. 
 Tina’s work has been applied to personalized search on the World-Wide Web, statistical indices of large-scale scientific simulation data, fraud detection, mobile ad targeting, cyber situational awareness, drug discovery, democracy and online discourse, and ethics in machine learning. Her algorithms have been incorporated into systems used by governments and industry (e.g., IBM System G Graph Analytics), as well as open-source software (e.g., Stanford Network Analysis Project). Tina received an Outstanding Mentor Award from the U.S. Department of Energy’s Office of Science in 2010, became an ISI Foundation Fellow in 2019, was named one of the  100 Brilliant Women in AI Ethics  in 2021, received  Northeastern University’s Excellence in Research and Creative Activity Award  in 2022, was awarded the  Lagrange Prize in 2023 , and was elected  Fellow of the Network Science Society  in 2023. 
 View her  website  or  LinkedIn .

description:
This special screening of the film adaptation of  Black Metal  is followed by a discussion with artist and curator Ari Melenciano. 
 
 
 ABOUT THE EXHIBITION Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby September 23 – December 14, 2025 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: MSW Program Virtual Current Student Panel
description:
Discover What’s Possible in Our MSW Program Our  MSW program  prepares leaders in social work to help children, youth and families in a diverse local and global society. The program aims to prepare advanced practitioners to provide a range of clinical and advocacy services to vulnerable children, adolescents and their families. We're hosting a   virtual current student panel November 5 at 7:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. Program Snapshot 
 
 Credits: On-campus and  online  - 60 | Advanced Standing - 33 
 Program Length: 2 - 4 years  
 Modality: On-campus or online  
 Cohort: Day option or evening option ( synchronous and asynchronous in online program ) 
 
 Meet the Panelists  
 
 Allegra Addeo, Maywood School District 
 Alanna Matos, St. Mary's General Hospital 
 Tim Nee, Mental Health Association, Center for Behavioral Health 
 Skyler Segal, Mental Health Association of Essex/Morris

title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Music Therapy Day 2025
description:
MUSIC THERAPY DAY 
 NOVEMBER 6, 2025 9AM–1PM Leshowitz Recital Hall Chapin Hall, Cali School of Music 
 The Music Therapy faculty invite you to explore the field of music therapy as a career and discover Montclair State University’s John J. Cali School of Music program. The morning will include an introduction to the profession, video examples of music therapy in action, an overview of Montclair’s undergraduate and graduate programs, and opportunities for questions, conversation, and a tour of the Cali School—hosted by faculty and current students. 
 Schedule 9:45–10:00AM  Arrival (Chapin Hall Lobby) 10:00–10:15AM  Greetings and Orientation to Montclair State University and The John J. Cali School of Music 10:15–10:45AM  An Introduction and Overview of the Music Therapy Profession 10:45–11:30AM  Video Examples of Music Therapy in Action 11:30AM–Noon  The Music Therapy Programs at Montclair State Noon–12:30PM  Questions and Conversation 12:30–1PM  Tour of Cali School of Music 
 REGISTER:   https://bit.ly/mt-day-2025 
 VISIT US! To learn more about the Music Therapy Program or request additional information, please contact Dr. Brian Abrams at  abramsb@montclair.edu . 
 Please Note: Complimentary parking passes will be provided for guests who park in the Red Hawk Deck.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: RULE OF LAW AND THE CORE AMERICAN INSTITUTIONS
description:
The Declaration of Independence lays out a legalistic argument for separation from Great Britain. With this start, the founders placed the primacy of law as bedrock principle of a new nation. Many of the features ultimately enshrined in the Constitution rest upon this base including separation of powers, checks and balances, judicial independence, federalism and state’s rights. Our system of market capitalism stems from the same starting point with an emphasis on property rights, contract and state enforcement. 
 Join President Koppell for a lecture and discussion tracing rule of law as a through-line of American democracy that predates the founding of the United States and has served as the logic model for the conflicts and controversies that have shaped the American experiment. 
 Event is open to all

title: Real Talk: Love, Friendship & Boundaries
description: This interactive workshop, hosted by Health Promotion, will focus on building and maintaining healthy connections in friendships, dating, and intimate relationships. Participants will explore expectations within different types of relationships, learn how to set and respect boundaries, and identify key characteristics of healthy partnerships such as trust, respect, communication, and equality. Through engaging discussion and activities, students will leave with tools to strengthen their personal relationships and recognize red flags in unhealthy dynamics. This program encourages reflection and empowers students to make informed, positive choices in their interactions with others.

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Viola Masterclass with Lawrence Dutton of the Emerson String Quartet
description:
Viola Masterclass with Lawrence Dutton 
 Grammy-winning violist  Lawrence Dutton  of the  Emerson String Quartet  will lead a masterclass on chamber music artistry, ensemble collaboration, and expressive string interpretation. 
 Bio: 
 Lawrence Dutton  is the violist of the 9-time Grammy-winning  Emerson String Quartet,  with over 50 recordings and collaborations with artists such as  Isaac Stern, Renée Fleming,  Sir Paul McCartney,  and  Joshua Bell.  He has performed with leading string quartets and piano trios, appeared as soloist with major U.S. and European orchestras, and been featured at top festivals including A spen, Ravinia, Santa Fe,  and  Music@Menlo . 
 Since 2001, he has served as Artistic Director of the  Hoch Chamber Music Series.  He is Distinguished Professor of Viola and Chamber Music at Stony Brook University and Distinguished Artist at the Robert McDuffie Center for Strings at Mercer University. A Juilliard graduate, he holds multiple honorary doctorates and, with the Emerson Quartet, has received the  Avery Fisher Award, Chamber Music America’s National Service Award,  and induction into the  American Classical Music Hall of Fame.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: Horseback Riding Trip
description:
Learn horseback riding basics at the Echo Lakes Stable. We'll go on a gorgeous trail ride through beautiful fields and trails that follow  the path next to mountain sides with swiftly running streams. NOTE: WEIGHT LIMIT 225lb 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register online through  Fusion , in the Student Recreation Center's main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340).  Registration opens on Monday, October 20 at 10 a.m. 
 Cost for Students $20 
 
   
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, November 8th, 2025 
 9:30 a.m. - 3 p.m. 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
   
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, long pants, sneakers/boots and sunscreen. 
 Potential Hazards:  Unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites and injury by running, including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures, injuries by animal including bites, falls from height and injuries from hooves including kicks and steps.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Immersive Residency with Mezzo-soprano  Isabel Leonard and University Symphony Orchestra
description:
Join us for the  fifth annual  reimagined professional residency program at the John J. Cali School of Music, where week-long residencies with top artists and ensembles offer students immersive opportunities to collaborate, learn, and explore the evolving, often nontraditional landscape of music today. 
 Three-time Grammy Award-winning mezzo-soprano  Isabel Leonard  joins the Cali School of Music for a multi-day residency featuring masterclasses, workshops, and a performance with the  University Symphony Orchestra . On campus, Leonard will work with undergraduate and graduate students on acting for singers, artist–manager collaboration, and opera interpretation. Renowned for her expressive artistry and commanding stage presence, she continues to perform leading roles with major opera houses worldwide, including Carmen and Frida at  The Metropolitan Opera,  Angelina at  Bayerische Staatsoper,  and  L’enfant et les sortilèges  with the  San Diego Symphony.  Leonard also serves as a Perspectives Artist at  Carnegie Hall  and appears with the  New York Philharmonic  and international recital stages this season. 
 Performance of  Knoxville: Summer of 1915  with University Symphony Orchestra,  Kyle Ritenauer,  conductor 
 Followed by a vocal masterclass with Cali voice students. 
 FREE TICKETS:  https://bit.ly/CaliLeonardConcert

title: South Mountain Preserve Easy Hike (Fairy Hike)
description:
Get ready to frolic amongst the fairies as we go through the South Mountain preserve fairy trail, decorated with woodland creature houses along our beautiful walk through nature. As you join us on this magical hike, make sure to wear comfortable sneakers or hiking shoes and bring a water bottle! 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register online through  Fusion , in the Student Recreation Center’s main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Registration opens October 20th 
 Cost for Students $10 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Sunday, November 9, 2025 
 10:00 am – 5:00 pm 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, weather appropriate clothing, boots or sneakers, and sunscreen. 
 Potential Hazards:  Poisonous plants/allergies; insect bites; unpredictable weather changes; sunburn/heat exhaustion; dehydration; steep, rocky and/or slippery terrain; rolling or falling rocks; snakes and large animals; and injuries including sprains/strains, abrasions, lacerations and fractures.

title: DREAM MONTHLY: From Disability Rights to Disability Justice
description:
November Pause for Change continues to discuss the evolution from Disability rights to DISABILITY JUSTICE! We will also explore the working definition of ableism. The discussion will highlight the differences between Disability Justice and Disability Rights, delving into the broader framework of the Disability Justice movement. We will also examine the key principles that drive this movement. As a creative and reflective exercise, each participant will receive a page from the Sins Invalid coloring book to personalize with their initials or designs, providing a meaningful way to engage with the concepts discussed. This meeting is an opportunity to deepen our understanding of Disability Justice and its impact on advocacy and inclusivity. 
 Welcome to the  ​Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring (DREAM)  Group for College Students with Disabilities and Allies! We invite and welcome you! Monthly Monday Meetings will be held on Mondays of each month! Put in your Calendar in advance, as a reminder! This is an in person event & online, MASKS are HIGHLY ENCOURAGED and will be provided. 
 If you cant make in-person - no worries - join us online! https://montclair.zoom.us/j/92835077081?pwd=wbXrCoUk5daw91yU3NAwY3aEXaGkbj.1

description: Step into the ballroom and step out of Montclair. For one night only, the walls will come alive with the sights, sounds, and flavors of North Africa. Wander through a celebration of the region’s rich traditions, taste dishes that carry the soul of the Maghreb and beyond, hear music that moves across deserts and cities alike, and feel the warmth of community that ties it all together. Expect food, culture, and stories that make you feel like you’ve traveled across the Mediterranean without ever leaving campus. North Africa is coming to you. Don’t miss it!

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: SA Awareness & Prevention with the Sisters of  Phi Sigma Sigma & Theta Phi Alpha
location: University Hall 1070 - Phyllis & Gerald LeBoff Lecture Hall
description:
Join the sisters of Phi Sigma Sigma and Theta Phi Alpha for an important evening focused on sexual assault awareness, prevention, and empowerment. This collaborative event is dedicated to fostering a safe, supportive, and informed campus community. 
 Through educational resources and guest speakers. Attendees will gain valuable insights into consent, bystander intervention, and how to support survivors. Our goal is to create a space for open dialogue, learning, and collective action against sexual violence. 
 Whether you're seeking knowledge, resources, or ways to get involved, this event welcomes all students to be part of the conversation and the movement toward a safer community!

title: Food Recovery Network General Body Meeting
description:
We’re thrilled to invite you to our General Body Meetings! This is a fantastic opportunity to get involved, meet fellow members, and learn about the exciting plans and initiatives we have in store. 
 - Get to know the team, hear about our mission, and understand the goals and vision for this year. We’ll also introduce key members and roles within the organization. 
 - Learn about upcoming events, projects, and opportunities for involvement. We'll outline our plans and how you can contribute to our success. 
 - Connect with other members, make new friends, and build relationships within our community.  
 - Find out how you can volunteer, join committees, or participate in special projects. We’ll provide information on various roles and how you can make an impact. 
 Whether you’re a new member or a returning one, your presence and participation will help shape the future of our organization.  
 We look forward to meeting you and embarking on this exciting journey together!

description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Weekly Wednesday Zoom Check-ins @ 8pm
description:
Weekly meetings Description @ 8pm on Wednesdays 
 Welcome to the  ​ Disability Rights, Education, Activism, & Mentoring   (DREAM)  Group for College Students with  Disabilities and Allies!  We invite and welcome you, (undergraduates, grad students and allies) to a supportive discussion with peers. Whether you would like to just come hang out with us, meet each other, talk about your experiences as students, vent about life or chill and laugh, we can do it all! We can provide each other with community care!  
 If you are coming as an Ally here are a few ways to be an ally to the disabled community: 1) Check your own internalized ableism. 2) Understand that not every disability is visible to you. 3) If you notice inaccessibility, speak up! Advocate for us. 4) Attend events that center disabled voices. 5) If a person in your life has a disability, take the time to learn about it. 6) Make mistakes, apologize, and learn from them. 7) Consume some media (made by disabled people) about disability. 
 Meetings will be held online via Zoom

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: On View: The Age of Black Metal by Afrotectopia
description:
Embark on your own interstellar voyage in  The Age of Black Metal  by Afrotectopia. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 Segal Gallery 
 Tuesday – Friday, 12 – 4 pm 
   
 Kasser Lobby 
 Monday – Friday, 12 – 6 pm 
   
 We're also open on select Saturdays of the month and  by appointment . 
   
 About the Exhibition: 
 On view through December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
   
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.
